title: 2 Samuel Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 4.

questions.question: What happened to Saul's son when he heard that Abner was dead?
questions.correctAnswer: His hands were feeble
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:1 states that when Saul's son heard that Abner was dead, his hands were feeble and the Israelites were troubled.

questions.question: Who were the two captains of bands under Saul's son?
questions.correctAnswer: Baanah and Rechab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:2 identifies Baanah and Rechab as the two captains of bands under Saul's son.

questions.question: Where did the Beerothites flee to and sojourn?
questions.correctAnswer: Gittaim
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:3 states that the Beerothites fled to Gittaim and were sojourners there.

questions.question: How did Mephibosheth become lame?
options: He fell as his nurse fled
questions.correctAnswer: He fell as his nurse fled
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:4 explains that Mephibosheth became lame because he fell while his nurse was fleeing.

questions.question: At what time of day did Rechab and Baanah come to Ishbosheth's house?
options: At the heat of the day
questions.correctAnswer: At the heat of the day
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:5 states that Rechab and Baanah came about the heat of the day to Ishbosheth's house.

questions.question: What did Rechab and Baanah do to Ishbosheth?
options: They smote him under the fifth rib and beheaded him
questions.correctAnswer: They smote him under the fifth rib and beheaded him
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:6-7 describes how Rechab and Baanah killed Ishbosheth by smiting him and beheading him.

questions.question: What did Rechab and Baanah do with Ishbosheth’s head?
options: They brought it to David in Hebron
They took it to Saul's son
They threw it into the plain
questions.correctAnswer: They brought it to David in Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:8 says they brought Ishbosheth’s head to David in Hebron.

questions.question: What reason did Rechab and Baanah give to David for killing Ishbosheth?
options: That the LORD had avenged David of Saul and his seed
That Ishbosheth was a friend of David
That they wanted to serve Saul's son
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD had avenged David of Saul and his seed
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:8 records their claim that the LORD had avenged David by killing Saul's son Ishbosheth.

questions.question: How did David respond to Rechab and Baanah after hearing about Ishbosheth's death?
options: He condemned them and had them killed
questions.correctAnswer: He condemned them and had them killed
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:9-12 shows David condemning them and ordering their execution for murdering a righteous man.

questions.question: What punishment did David command for Rechab and Baanah?
options: They were slain and their hands and feet cut off
questions.correctAnswer: They were slain and their hands and feet cut off
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:12 describes their execution and mutilation as commanded by David.

questions.question: True or False: Mephibosheth was five years old when he became lame.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:4 states Mephibosheth was five years old when he became lame.

questions.question: True or False: Ishbosheth was killed while he was outside his house.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:6-7 explains that Ishbosheth was killed in his bed inside his house.

questions.question: True or False: David took the head of Ishbosheth and buried it in the sepulchre of Abner.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:12 states that David buried Ishbosheth's head in Abner's sepulchre in Hebron.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'And when Saul's son heard that Abner was dead in ________, his hands were feeble.'
questions.correctAnswer: Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:1 states that Abner was dead in Hebron when Saul's son heard the news.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'And they smote him under the ______ rib.'
questions.correctAnswer: fifth
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:6 says they smote Ishbosheth under the fifth rib.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 4:1 teach us about trusting God in times of fear and uncertainty?
options: We should remain calm and rely on God's plan
We should isolate ourselves from others
We must panic and lose faith
questions.correctAnswer: We should remain calm and rely on God's plan
questions.explanation: Verse 1 shows that Saul's son was troubled and his hands were feeble upon hearing of Abner's death. This teaches us that fear and uncertainty can weaken us, but trusting God instead of panic is the biblical response. Trusting God's sovereignty helps us overcome fear. See also verses 9-11 on trusting God's justice.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness over a rival's success. Based on 2 Samuel 4:8-11, what biblical truth would you share about handling enemies?
options: God will bring justice in His time, so we should avoid taking revenge
We should quickly punish enemies ourselves
We should ignore all wrongs and not care about justice
We should seek to harm them first
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring justice in His time, so we should avoid taking revenge
questions.explanation: David’s response to Rechab and Baanah in verses 9-11 shows he did not condone their violent act against Ishbosheth, emphasizing that God’s justice is to be trusted rather than personal revenge. This models humility and reliance on God’s righteousness.

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 4:4 teach us about God's care for those with disabilities in a family context?
options: God values and includes those with disabilities within His family
Disabled family members are to be hidden away
Disabilities are always a punishment from God
Disabled persons cannot be part of God’s promises
questions.correctAnswer: God values and includes those with disabilities within His family
questions.explanation: Verse 4 describes Mephibosheth, who was lame but still recognized as Jonathan's son and part of the family line. This shows God’s care for all members, valuing them regardless of physical challenges, encouraging believers to lovingly include all in family and fellowship.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 4:5-7 instruct us about honesty and integrity in our work and interactions?
options: We should not use deceit or violence to accomplish our goals
It is acceptable to lie if it benefits us
We should avoid working with others
We must always prioritize success over honesty
questions.correctAnswer: We should not use deceit or violence to accomplish our goals
questions.explanation: Rechab and Baanah came pretending to fetch wheat but killed Ishbosheth deceitfully. David condemned their act (verses 8-11), teaching believers to uphold honesty and integrity rather than resorting to violence or deceit in daily life and work.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to take justice into their own hands. What does 2 Samuel 4:11-12 reveal about God's call to humility and patience?
options: God requires us to wait for His timing and not act wickedly
We should immediately punish wrongdoers ourselves
It is acceptable to seek revenge if we feel justified
Justice is not important in Christian living
questions.correctAnswer: God requires us to wait for His timing and not act wickedly
questions.explanation: David condemned Rechab and Baanah for killing Ishbosheth and had them executed, showing God’s justice but also the necessity of proper authority and timing in judgment. This teaches patience and humility in facing injustice.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 4:8, what principle about sharing testimony and witnessing can be applied in evangelism?
options: We should share truth boldly, trusting God to use it for His purposes
We must only share good news and avoid difficult truths
Evangelism should be done quietly and in secret
questions.correctAnswer: We should share truth boldly, trusting God to use it for His purposes
questions.explanation: Rechab and Baanah boldly presented Ishbosheth's head to David claiming to have done God’s work. While their actions were wrong, the principle of boldly presenting facts can inspire believers to share the Gospel confidently and trust God’s sovereign work.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 4:12 teach about stewardship and respect for the dead within the church community?
options: Believers should honor the dead properly, as David buried Ishbosheth's head
The dead are unimportant and can be discarded
Respect is only for the living
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should honor the dead properly, as David buried Ishbosheth's head
questions.explanation: David ensured Ishbosheth’s head was buried in Abner’s sepulchre (verse 12), showing respect and stewardship towards the dead, reflecting biblical values of honoring those who have passed and maintaining family and community dignity.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 4:9-10, David rewarded those who brought him news about Saul's death.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David states in verse 10 that when someone told him Saul was dead, he killed that man instead of rewarding him, illustrating that he did not reward violence or wrongdoing even if it seemed beneficial.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter shows that faithfulness to God includes rejecting wicked actions even when they appear to benefit us.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David's refusal to accept Rechab and Baanah's violent act against Ishbosheth (verses 9-11) teaches believers to reject wickedness regardless of apparent benefits, demonstrating faithfulness to God's commands.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In 2 Samuel 4:6, Rechab and Baanah struck Ishbosheth under the ____ rib.
questions.correctAnswer: fifth
questions.explanation: Verse 6 explicitly states that Ishbosheth was struck under the fifth rib, indicating the specific detail of the violent act.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 4:2-3 teach us about the importance of family heritage and maintaining faithfulness even in exile or difficulty?
options: The Beerothites maintained their identity even while sojourning in Gittaim
Family heritage is unimportant and can be forgotten
Exile means abandoning faith and community
Difficult circumstances justify breaking family ties
questions.correctAnswer: The Beerothites maintained their identity even while sojourning in Gittaim
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 describe the Beerothites fleeing to Gittaim but still recognized as part of Benjamin, showing that maintaining identity and faithfulness to heritage is vital even during hardship or displacement.

questions.question: A believer is facing trials that make them feel weak and discouraged. What can 2 Samuel 4:1 teach about responding to such moments spiritually?
options: Recognize weakness but seek God's strength and peace
Give up and withdraw from community
Act rashly to fix all problems immediately
Ignore the feelings and pretend all is well
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize weakness but seek God's strength and peace
questions.explanation: Verse 1 describes Saul's son’s feeble hands and Israel’s trouble, showing human weakness in trials. Believers are encouraged to acknowledge their weakness and depend on God’s strength and peace through prayer and trust.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 4:9-12 exemplify the biblical virtue of justice within church leadership?
options: David exercises righteous judgment by punishing wickedness even among allies
Leaders should ignore wrongdoing to avoid conflict
Justice is subjective and leaders should be lenient
Leaders must always protect their supporters regardless of actions
questions.correctAnswer: David exercises righteous judgment by punishing wickedness even among allies
questions.explanation: David commands the execution of Rechab and Baanah for their violent act (verses 11-12), demonstrating that leaders must uphold justice impartially and maintain integrity in the community.

questions.question: What does the account of Mephibosheth in 2 Samuel 4:4 teach about parenting with biblical wisdom and care?
options: Parents and caregivers must protect and care for children, especially vulnerable ones
Children with disabilities should be rejected
Only perfect children are valued in God’s kingdom
Parents should not worry about a child's physical condition
questions.correctAnswer: Parents and caregivers must protect and care for children, especially vulnerable ones
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth’s nurse fled to protect him, indicating the importance of caregiving and protection. This encourages parents and believers to care for all children with love and wisdom.

questions.question: How does the story of Ishbosheth's death in 2 Samuel 4 teach about humility and contentment when facing opposition in leadership or family?
options: Leaders should trust God’s plan rather than seize power by violence
It is acceptable to kill rivals to gain control
Discontent should be expressed through rebellion
Power struggles are necessary for success
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should trust God’s plan rather than seize power by violence
questions.explanation: Ishbosheth was killed by violent men seeking power (verses 5-7), but David condemned this. The passage encourages humility and reliance on God’s timing rather than violent ambition in leadership and family.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 4.

questions.question: What was the condition of Saul's son when he heard that Abner was dead according to 2 Samuel 4?
questions.correctAnswer: His hands were feeble
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:1 states that when Saul's son heard that Abner was dead, 'his hands were feeble,' indicating his shock and weakness.

questions.question: Who were the two men captains of bands serving Saul's son?
questions.correctAnswer: Baanah and Rechab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:2 identifies the two captains as Baanah and Rechab, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite.

questions.question: From which people group did Baanah and Rechab come?
questions.correctAnswer: Beerothites
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:2 clarifies that Baanah and Rechab were sons of Rimmon a Beerothite, belonging to the children of Benjamin.

questions.question: What happened to Jonathan’s son Mephibosheth when his nurse fled after hearing the news of Saul and Jonathan?
options: He became lame of his feet
He was hidden in a cave
questions.correctAnswer: He became lame of his feet
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:4 describes how Mephibosheth became lame when his nurse hurriedly fled and he fell.

questions.question: In what manner did Baanah and Rechab kill Ishbosheth?
options: Struck him under the fifth rib and beheaded him
questions.correctAnswer: Struck him under the fifth rib and beheaded him
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:6-7 narrates that they smote Ishbosheth under the fifth rib, killed and beheaded him.

questions.question: What excuse did Baanah and Rechab give David for killing Ishbosheth?
options: That the LORD had avenged David of Saul and his seed
That Ishbosheth was rebelling against David
That they sought a reward from David
That Ishbosheth was conspiring with the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD had avenged David of Saul and his seed
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:8 records Baanah and Rechab presenting Ishbosheth’s head to David claiming the LORD had avenged him.

questions.question: How did David respond to Baanah and Rechab's deed of killing Ishbosheth?
options: He condemned and executed them for murder
questions.correctAnswer: He condemned and executed them for murder
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:9-12 records David's condemnation of the murder and ordering their execution.

questions.question: What punishment did David order for Baanah and Rechab after their murder of Ishbosheth?
options: They were slain, their hands and feet cut off, and hanged over a pool in Hebron
They were made servants in David's household
questions.correctAnswer: They were slain, their hands and feet cut off, and hanged over a pool in Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:12 details David's command to kill them, cut off their hands and feet, and hang them over the pool.

questions.question: True or False: Mephibosheth was lame because he was born with a disability.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:4 explains Mephibosheth became lame when his nurse fled and he fell, not from birth.

questions.question: Which of the following best represents the literary theme demonstrated by David’s reaction to Ishbosheth’s murder?
questions.correctAnswer: Justice and righteousness
questions.explanation: David's execution of the murderers in 2 Samuel 4:9-12 reflects a theme of justice and righteousness rather than political expediency.

questions.question: What cultural significance is reflected in the act of bringing Ishbosheth’s head to David?
options: It symbolized proof of death and submission
It was a customary gift to kings of spoils
It was a sign of alliance with the Philistines
It indicated a demand for ransom
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized proof of death and submission
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:8 shows the head was brought as tangible proof of Ishbosheth's death and an attempt to gain favor with David.

questions.question: The name Mephibosheth means 'exterminator of shame.' How might this be ironic in light of 2 Samuel 4?
options: Because Mephibosheth was lame and marginalized
Because he became king after Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Because Mephibosheth was lame and marginalized
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:4 depicts Mephibosheth as lame and vulnerable, contrasting with the meaning of his name, illustrating irony.

questions.question: What does the killing of Ishbosheth in his own bed symbolize in the narrative's development?
options: The end of Saul’s dynasty's political power
questions.correctAnswer: The end of Saul’s dynasty's political power
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:5-7 describes Ishbosheth’s assassination in his bed, symbolizing the violent end of Saul’s line’s rule.

questions.question: How does the fate of Baanah and Rechab compare with the earlier killing of Saul by an Amalekite in 1 Samuel 31:4-6 and 2 Samuel 1:6-16?
options: David punishes Baanah and Rechab but rewards the Amalekite’s killer
David punishes both groups for killing Saul or his descendants
David rewards Baanah and Rechab as he did the Amalekite
questions.correctAnswer: David punishes Baanah and Rechab but rewards the Amalekite’s killer
questions.explanation: Unlike Baanah and Rechab, David executed the Amalekite who claimed to kill Saul (2 Samuel 1:14-16), showing his stance against murder of God's anointed.

questions.question: What historical context does the flight of the Beerothites to Gittaim, as noted in 2 Samuel 4, suggest?
options: Ongoing tribal conflicts and displacement within Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Ongoing tribal conflicts and displacement within Benjamin
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:3 mentions Beerothites fleeing to Gittaim, indicating social instability and tribal displacement in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: True or False: David personally killed Ishbosheth upon hearing of Saul’s death.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:10 clarifies David did not kill Saul or Ishbosheth but punished those who killed them unlawfully.

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the immediate reaction of Saul's son and all Israel upon hearing of Abner's death?
options: Their hands were feeble and they were troubled
questions.correctAnswer: Their hands were feeble and they were troubled
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:1 tells us that when Saul's son heard of Abner's death, his hands were feeble and all Israel was troubled. This shows the distress and instability caused by Abner's death, consistent with the biblical theme of fear and uncertainty in times of political upheaval (compare Judges 17:6; Psalm 55:4-5; Ecclesiastes 8:11; Acts 17:7).

questions.question: Who were the two captains of bands serving Saul's son?
questions.correctAnswer: Baanah and Rechab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:2 identifies Baanah and Rechab as the two captains of bands under Saul's son. Their role as military leaders underlines the divided loyalties and political tension after Saul's death, echoing the recurring biblical theme of power struggles (compare 1 Chronicles 12:2; Joshua 1:14; Judges 6:12; 2 Kings 11:4).

questions.question: What was the condition of Jonathan's son Mephibosheth when the news of Saul and Jonathan's death reached him?
options: He was lame of his feet
questions.correctAnswer: He was lame of his feet
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:4 describes Mephibosheth as lame of his feet due to an accident when his nurse fled with him. This physical disability highlights themes of human frailty and God's sovereign care for those with disabilities, paralleling biblical truths about God's grace toward the weak (compare 2 Corinthians 12:9; John 9:1-3; Psalm 34:18; Isaiah 35:6).

questions.question: How did Rechab and Baanah gain access to Ishbosheth's house?
options: They came pretending to fetch wheat
questions.correctAnswer: They came pretending to fetch wheat
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 4:5-6, Rechab and Baanah came into Ishbosheth's house as though to fetch wheat, then killed him. This deceitful act exemplifies the sinful nature of treachery and murder, reflecting the biblical condemnation of such actions (compare Proverbs 6:16-19; Exodus 20:13; Romans 1:29; Psalm 7:14).

questions.question: Where was Ishbosheth when he was killed by Rechab and Baanah?
options: Lying on his bed at noon
questions.correctAnswer: Lying on his bed at noon
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:5-6 specifies that Ishbosheth was lying on his bed at noon when he was slain. This detail emphasizes the vulnerability and betrayal involved, illustrating the biblical theme that wickedness can strike unexpectedly even in moments of apparent safety (compare Psalm 41:9; Matthew 26:45-46; Proverbs 14:32; 1 Samuel 19:10).

questions.question: What did Rechab and Baanah do to Ishbosheth after killing him?
options: They beheaded him and took his head away
They displayed his body in the city square
questions.correctAnswer: They beheaded him and took his head away
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:7 describes that after killing Ishbosheth, Rechab and Baanah beheaded him and took his head. This gruesome act signified political assassination and was meant as a trophy, reflecting the biblical portrayal of violent power struggles and the consequences of sin (compare Judges 9:53; 1 Samuel 17:51; 2 Kings 9:24; Revelation 20:4).

questions.question: To whom did Rechab and Baanah bring the head of Ishbosheth?
questions.correctAnswer: David in Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:8 states that they brought Ishbosheth's head to David in Hebron, claiming to have avenged the king. This act attempts to curry favor with David but reveals the complex dynamics of justice and vengeance in biblical history (compare Genesis 4:15; 2 Samuel 3:27; Psalm 94:1; Romans 12:19).

questions.question: How did David respond to Rechab and Baanah's act of killing Ishbosheth?
options: He took the head and praised them
questions.correctAnswer: He condemned and executed them
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 4:9-12, David condemns Rechab and Baanah for murdering a righteous man in his own house and orders their execution. This response underscores David's respect for justice and the sanctity of life, consistent with biblical teaching against murder and the principle that even political enemies deserve fair treatment (compare Exodus 20:13; Deuteronomy 19:11; Proverbs 28:17; Matthew 5:21-22).

questions.question: What was done to Rechab and Baanah after their execution?
options: Their hands and feet were cut off and they were hanged
They were given a warrior's burial
questions.correctAnswer: Their hands and feet were cut off and they were hanged
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:12 records that after killing Rechab and Baanah, David's men cut off their hands and feet and hung them over the pool in Hebron, a form of public humiliation and punishment. This reflects biblical justice and the deterrence of violent crime (compare Deuteronomy 25:12; Jeremiah 22:18; Luke 23:39-43; Romans 13:4).

questions.question: Where was the head of Ishbosheth buried?
options: In the sepulchre of Abner in Hebron
In the royal tomb of Saul
questions.correctAnswer: In the sepulchre of Abner in Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 4:12 states that after the execution of the murderers, the head of Ishbosheth was buried in Abner’s sepulchre in Hebron. This burial together signifies respect for the fallen leaders and acknowledges God's providential plan despite human sinfulness (compare Genesis 50:25; 1 Kings 2:10; 2 Chronicles 24:25; John 19:38-42).

questions.question: What theological principle does David’s refusal to accept the murderers' 'gift' of Ishbosheth's head illustrate?
options: God’s justice requires condemnation of wicked deeds, even if politically advantageous
Murder is justified if it benefits the king
Political power is gained by any means necessary
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice requires condemnation of wicked deeds, even if politically advantageous
questions.explanation: David’s rejection of the murderers (2 Samuel 4:9-11) demonstrates that God’s justice supersedes political expediency. This aligns with biblical teaching that righteousness and justice must prevail over violence and deceit (compare Micah 6:8; Proverbs 21:15; Isaiah 1:17; Romans 3:25-26).

questions.question: What does the episode of Mephibosheth being lame suggest about God's providence in human weakness?
options: God cares for and includes those who are physically weak or disabled
Physical weakness disqualifies one from God's promises
Disability is always a result of sin
Only the strong are chosen by God
questions.correctAnswer: God cares for and includes those who are physically weak or disabled
questions.explanation: Mephibosheth’s lameness (2 Samuel 4:4) illustrates that God’s covenant blessings and care extend to the weak and disabled, consistent with biblical affirmations of God’s grace towards all (compare John 9:1-3; 2 Corinthians 12:7-10; Psalm 146:8; Isaiah 35:3-6).

questions.question: What does the killing of Ishbosheth in his own house reveal about the nature of sin and human depravity?
options: Sin leads to betrayal and violence even in places of supposed safety
Sin only affects those outside the community
Sin respects sanctuaries and private homes
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to betrayal and violence even in places of supposed safety
questions.explanation: The murder of Ishbosheth at home (2 Samuel 4:6-7) highlights how sin corrupts human relationships and leads to betrayal, even in sacred or private spaces. This aligns with biblical teachings on the pervasive nature of sin and its destructive consequences (compare Genesis 4:8; Jeremiah 17:9; Romans 3:23; 1 John 1:8).

questions.question: How does David’s conduct towards Rechab and Baanah contrast with their actions, illustrating biblical ethics?
options: David upholds justice and condemns murder, while they commit treacherous killing
David rewards violence, they are loyal soldiers
David ignores evil deeds, they act justly
Both act similarly to gain power
questions.correctAnswer: David upholds justice and condemns murder, while they commit treacherous killing
questions.explanation: David’s condemnation and execution of the murderers (2 Samuel 4:9-12) contrasts sharply with their treacherous act, demonstrating biblical ethics that require justice and righteousness over political gain (compare Psalm 82:3-4; Proverbs 21:15; Isaiah 33:15; Romans 12:17-21).

questions.question: What does the narrative of 2 Samuel 4 teach about God's sovereignty amid human political turmoil?
options: God’s plan prevails despite human sin and violence
God abandons those in political conflict
God supports any faction that gains power
questions.correctAnswer: God’s plan prevails despite human sin and violence
questions.explanation: Despite the murders and political chaos in 2 Samuel 4, God's sovereignty is evident as David’s kingship is affirmed and justice administered. This reflects the biblical theme that God's redemptive plan transcends human sinfulness (compare Genesis 50:20; Romans 8:28; Psalm 75:6-7; Isaiah 46:9-10).

questions.question: What Christological theme can be seen in David’s righteous leadership in contrast to Ishbosheth’s murder?
options: David as a type of the righteous king who judges evil and upholds justice
David as a warrior who rules by force
The rejection of kingship as God’s plan
questions.correctAnswer: David as a type of the righteous king who judges evil and upholds justice
questions.explanation: David’s just response to murderers and his role as God’s anointed king prefigure Christ’s righteous kingship who judges sin and establishes justice (compare Psalm 72:1-4; Isaiah 11:1-5; Luke 1:32-33; Revelation 19:11-16).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is revealed through David’s refusal to accept the killing of Ishbosheth as a political advantage?
options: God’s holiness and justice demand condemnation of sin
God is indifferent to human actions
God only values the strong and victorious
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holiness and justice demand condemnation of sin
questions.explanation: David’s response (2 Samuel 4:9-11) reflects God's holy character and just nature, which require sin to be addressed even when politically convenient (compare Habakkuk 1:13; Isaiah 5:16; Romans 3:25-26; Hebrews 12:29).
